repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Add mappings for `goto_next` and `goto_prev`.

By default, disables the floating window. Considering `virtual_text` is enabled by default, having the float feels very noisy to me. Happy to be convinced otherwise. I'd also be happy to disable `virtual_text` by default and enable float popups for these maps.

comment_data.body:
It's considered "best practice" to wrap `<Plug>` mappings with parenths, like: `<Plug>(DiagnosticGotoNext)`. I think it may also make sense to say `<Plug>(VimDiagnosticNext)`. Prefixing with `vim` makes sense to me because it's `vim.diagnostic.goto_next()`.

Just a few thoughts.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -85,6 +85,10 @@ of these in your config by simply removing the mapping, e.g. ":unmap Y".
 	nnoremap <C-L> <Cmd>nohlsearch<Bar>diffupdate<CR><C-L>
 	inoremap <C-U> <C-G>u<C-U>
 	inoremap <C-W> <C-G>u<C-W>
+	nmap ]g <Plug>DiagnosticGotoNext

comment_data.body:
Hmm there is no connection from these plug mappings now to the help docs associated with what they do currently.

`<Plug>(VimDiagnosticGotoNext)` -> `vim.diagnostic.goto_next {}`.

I think perhaps they should be mentioned in the `*diagnostic-maps*` section.

It may even make more sense just to only make these `Plug` mappings and not actually map to any physical keyboard buttons, but I'm open to other people's opinions on that. We should at least link them in the help docs (in case they change in the future)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -85,6 +85,10 @@ of these in your config by simply removing the mapping, e.g. ":unmap Y".
 	nnoremap <C-L> <Cmd>nohlsearch<Bar>diffupdate<CR><C-L>
 	inoremap <C-U> <C-G>u<C-U>
 	inoremap <C-W> <C-G>u<C-W>
+	nmap ]g <Plug>(VimDiagnosticGotoNext)
+	nmap [g <Plug>(VimDiagnosticGotoPrev)
+	nmap ]G <Plug>(VimDiagnosticGotoLast)
+	nmap [G <Plug>(VimDiagnosticGotoFirst)

comment_data.body:
> It may even make more sense just to only make these Plug mappings and not actually map to any physical keyboard buttons, but I'm open to other people's opinions on that. We should at least link them in the help docs (in case they change in the future)

Personally I think this is only valuable if we do actually make default physical mappings. I'm not sure what the value add of providing default `<Plug>` mappings is since it's an equal burden on the user to create a `<Plug>` vs `<Cmd>` mapping, but the latter allows them to customize to their preferences.

If the consensus is that we don't want to add any new default mappings then I am fine with closing this.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -85,6 +85,10 @@ of these in your config by simply removing the mapping, e.g. ":unmap Y".
 	nnoremap <C-L> <Cmd>nohlsearch<Bar>diffupdate<CR><C-L>
 	inoremap <C-U> <C-G>u<C-U>
 	inoremap <C-W> <C-G>u<C-W>
+	nmap ]g <Plug>(VimDiagnosticGotoNext)
+	nmap [g <Plug>(VimDiagnosticGotoPrev)
+	nmap ]G <Plug>(VimDiagnosticGotoLast)
+	nmap [G <Plug>(VimDiagnosticGotoFirst)

comment_data.body:
Well `<Plug>` mapping is "future-proof", as in, if we change the module location, file path, naming scheme, default arguments, etc., the `<Plug>` mapping can evolve separately.

But I'm happy to put the default ones in :) It seems good to me. They just need to be linked in the docs.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -85,6 +85,10 @@ of these in your config by simply removing the mapping, e.g. ":unmap Y".
 	nnoremap <C-L> <Cmd>nohlsearch<Bar>diffupdate<CR><C-L>
 	inoremap <C-U> <C-G>u<C-U>
 	inoremap <C-W> <C-G>u<C-W>
+	nmap ]g <Plug>(VimDiagnosticGotoNext)
+	nmap [g <Plug>(VimDiagnosticGotoPrev)
+	nmap ]G <Plug>(VimDiagnosticGotoLast)
+	nmap [G <Plug>(VimDiagnosticGotoFirst)

comment_data.body: Since these are relative to the current buffer, this seems fine. For iterating the *global* diagnostics quickfix list, I'd suggest `]q` and `[q` (mnemonic: quickfix list), which was established by https://github.com/tpope/vim-unimpaired/ and has harmony with other quickfix-related potential mappings.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -340,6 +340,20 @@ Example: >lua
       end,
     })
 <
+==============================================================================
+MAPS                                                    *diagnostic-maps*
+
+                                                       *]d-default*
+]d                        Goto the next diagnostic in the buffer.
+                            |vim.diagnostic.goto_next()|
+                                                       *[d-default*
+[d                        Goto the previous diagnostic in the buffer.
+                            |vim.diagnostic.goto_prev()|

comment_data.body: nit: would be safer to reference the same local function instead of remapping. Not a blocker.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -143,6 +145,35 @@ do
     end
     vim.keymap.set({ 'o' }, 'gc', textobject_rhs, { desc = 'Comment textobject' })
   end
+
+  --- Map [d and ]d to move to the previous/next diagnostic. Map <C-W>d to open a floating window
+  --- for the diagnostic under the cursor.
+  ---
+  --- See |[d-default|, |]d-default|, and |CTRL-W_d-default|.
+  do
+    vim.keymap.set('n', ']d', function()
+      vim.diagnostic.goto_next({ float = false })
+    end, {
+      desc = 'Jump to the next diagnostic with the highest severity',
+    })
+
+    vim.keymap.set('n', '[d', function()
+      vim.diagnostic.goto_prev({ float = false })
+    end, {
+      desc = 'Jump to the previous diagnostic with the highest severity',
+    })
+
+    vim.keymap.set('n', '<C-W>d', function()
+      vim.diagnostic.open_float({ border = 'rounded' })
+    end, {
+      desc = 'Open a floating window showing diagnostics under the cursor',
+    })
+
+    vim.keymap.set('n', '<C-W><C-D>', '<C-W>d', {
+      remap = true,

comment_data.body: Is there a reason border is hardcoded here? Ideally it would use the default or pick up value from what was provided to `vim.diagnostic.config()`

comment_regular_data.body: +1 on no float, think probably this needs discussion though.

Another option would be to have a `float =  "smart"`, that shows it if virtual text got disabled.

But not sure if worth the complexity, given how easy it is to override the mapping.

I'd also tend to float=false as default as long as virt text  on is also the default

Perhaps this should be mapped to something like `<Plug>(NvimDiagnosticNext)` ? This way if we change implementation, options, etc, it does not matter? We don't have to keep updating the vim diff docs and everything
*ceterum censeo* we should move away from "silent" default mappings for everything; much better to provide functions to map and possibly a `vim.set_default_mappings({opt})` for people to opt-in.

I personally feel that vim.diagnostic and vim.lsp are first class citizens in the neovim world, and if there is the opportunity to make default mappings to alleviate some burden on the user (imagine if we said you had to map / to search) that is a pro. Ofc power-users can map things to their heart's content, but I think setting sane defaults is a good precedent in neovim.

Rebased. Updated to use `[d` and `]d` for jumping to diagnostics and `<C-W>d` for `open_float`. Open to better ideas on this last one, I also considered `gD` but that breaks too much with the builtin behavior (which some people might actually use). `<C-W>d` fits with the other `[d` builtin mappings and is pretty useless, and the `<C-W>` prefix commonly means "do something in another window", so it fits.

I might revisit https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/26745 as well so that we can also implement "goto first" and "goto last" functions for `[D` and `]D`, but we don't need to block this PR in the meantime.

cc @mfussenegger

I hope this isn't a noob question, but does the `[d`/`]d` mapping clash with the existing macro definition mapping?
https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/16513b30337523dc64707309ee7fe3dd2247266d/runtime/doc/tagsrch.txt#L777-L784

> I hope this isn't a noob question, but does the `[d`/`]d` mapping clash with the existing macro definition mapping?


Yes it does. We're making a deliberate decision to override these.

1. With tags files and LSP, the macro definition mappings are far less useful
2. Even without tags files or LSP, the macro definition mappings have limited usefulness. In C, it requires `'path'` to be properly configured. In other languages, `'define'` must be configured. Some ftplugins do this, but most don't, and even in the ones that do I am not sure that this is a commonly used feature.
3. If a user still wants to use the builtin mappings, they can opt out of the default diagnostic mappings with `vim.keymap.del`

I originally advocated for `[g` and `]g` to avoid clobbering the builtin mappings, but I've become convinced that preserving the default macro mappings is not worthwhile, particularly when the `[d` and `]d` mappings are so [widely used in the wild](https://sourcegraph.com/search?q=context:global+lang:Lua+vim.diagnostic.goto_next&patternType=keyword&sm=0).

_However_, if you do use these mappings regularly please chime in and say so. It's possible I'm underestimating the popularity of the macro mappings and if so we could reconsider using `]g` and `[g` instead.

> _However_, if you do use these mappings regularly please chime in and say so. It's possible I'm underestimating the popularity of the macro mappings and if so we could reconsider using `]g` and `[g` instead.

Thanks for the explanation. Nope, I never use the macro mappings. Happy with `[d`/`]d` for diagnostics.

title: feat(diagnostic): add default mappings for diagnostics
